Name: Hanno’s Periplus
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Clockwork (Causal Determinism)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Biology, Political Science / Law, Economics, History, Anthropology
Short Description: A brief but significant Carthaginian exploration report recounting a naval expedition along the West African coast, launched by the Carthaginian admiral Hanno. The purpose of the voyage was colonial and religious: to establish new settlements, reinforce Punic presence along the Atlantic, and found temples in honor of the gods. The expedition reportedly sailed beyond the Pillars of Hercules (Straits of Gibraltar), founding multiple colonies—such as Thymiaterion and Cerne. The original text was written in Punic and inscribed in the temple of Baal Hammon in Carthage. However, the work survives only in a Greek translation, probably created in the Hellenistic or early Roman period. The surviving Greek version may have been shortened or altered, possibly reflecting both translation issues and selective transmission.

Name: Kition Inscriptions
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: A series of short dedicatory texts, mostly engraved on stone stelae, written in Phoenician and found at the ancient site of Kition. These inscriptions record vows or offerings made by individuals to deities such as Baal, Astarte, or Melqart. The formulaic texts often follow a structure like: “To [Deity], [Name] son of [Name], has vowed/offered [object] for he heard his voice.” They served as ritual markers of devotion, fulfillment of vows, or gratitude for divine favor, and sometimes included curses against those who might tamper with the inscription.

Name: Tophet Inscriptions
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Phenomenology (Experiential), Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Grid (Systematic Structuralism)
Short Description: Short votive texts engraved on stone stelae found in sacred open-air precincts—Tophets—primarily at Carthage and other Phoenician sites. They typically record dedications to deities such as Tanit and Baal Hammon, often marking the fulfillment of a vow in exchange for divine favor. These inscriptions accompany urns containing the cremated remains of sacrificial offerings—sometimes animals, but mostly children—and reflect a ritual system involving sacrifice, divine reciprocity, and priestly authority. Though formulaic, they offer deep insights into the religious structure, symbolic order, and moral cosmology of the Punic world.
Jungian Archetypes Tags: Shadow, Mother Archetype, Terrible Mother, Father Archetype

Name: Punic Curse Tablets
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Dialectics (Conflict), Subversion (Negation), Monism (Single Principle)
Short Description: These inscribed lead sheets were typically buried or deposited in sacred spaces and served as ritual instruments of vengeance. Individuals used them to invoke deities or spirits—such as Baal Hammon or Tanit—to bring harm, misfortune, or death to enemies, thieves, or rivals. The curses often contained formulaic invocations, names of targets, and specific punishments requested. In many cases, the tablets were placed in tophets or other sanctified precincts closely associated with sacrificial rites, including animal and child sacrifice. These offerings may have accompanied or empowered the curses, binding the request to divine justice through blood or fire.

Name: Carthaginian Agricultural Treatise
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Dialectics (Conflict)
Short Description: A comprehensive 28-volume manual on farming, viticulture, livestock, and estate management. Although the original is lost, portions were preserved through Latin and Greek summaries and quotations, particularly after the Roman Senate ordered a Latin translation following the destruction of Carthage in 146 BCE. The text was highly valued for its practical empirical knowledge, and it shaped Roman agronomy through figures like Columella, Varro, and Pliny the Elder.

Name: Marseille Tariff
Short Description: An inscription discovered in Marseille, outlining the standardized payments and procedures for religious sacrifices. Likely composed by Carthaginian priests or officials, it sets the tariffs owed to priests for offering various animals, such as oxen, sheep, and birds, in temple rituals. Though technical in form, the text reflects a deeply structured religious economy, and reveals how ritual, law, and commerce were intertwined in the Punic diaspora. It offers rare insight into the sacred administrative practices of Western Phoenician communities in a multicultural port city.
Socio-political Tags: Priestly / Theocratic, Bureaucratic / Legal / Scribal, Merchant / Cosmopolitan

Name: Cippi of Melqart
Short Description: A pair of bilingual votive inscriptions commemorate a fulfilled vow by two Phoenician elites—Abdosir and Osirshamar—to the god Melqart, who is equated with Heracles in the Greek version. The inscriptions reflect a ritual act of devotion, a theocratic worldview, and serve as a key example of religious and cultural bridging between the Canaanite and Hellenistic symbolic systems. They are also crucial for the decipherment of Phoenician, due to their direct translation.
